tool.name: DasymetricPopulationMapping

param.name: Population_Features
param.dialogReference: The source units with population counts and a unique identifier to be converted to a raster.
param.pythonReference: The source units with population counts and a unique identifier to be converted to a raster.

param.name: Population_Count_Field
param.dialogReference: The field in Population Features that stores the population counts.
param.pythonReference: The field in Population Features that stores the population counts.

param.name: Population_Key_Field
param.dialogReference: The field in the Population Features that stores the unique identifier for the source unit.
param.pythonReference: The field in the Population Features that stores the unique identifier for the source unit.

param.name: Ancillary_Raster
param.dialogReference:
The ancillary raster dataset to be used to redistribute population. The cell size and spatial reference from the ancillary raster are used for all output rasters from this tool.

Land-use or land-cover are the most frequently used ancillary datasets, but any dataset that has classes of relatively homogenous population density could be used here.
param.pythonReference:
The ancillary raster dataset to be used to redistribute population. The cell size and spatial reference from the ancillary raster are used for all output rasters from this tool.

Land-use or land-cover are the most frequently used ancillary datasets, but any dataset that has classes of relatively homogenous population density could be used here.

param.name: Uninhabited_file
param.dialogReference: A feature class containing the uninhabited areas in the study area.
param.pythonReference: A feature class containing the uninhabited areas in the study area.

param.name: Minimum_Sample
param.dialogReference: This is the minimum threshold of representative source units required for an ancillary class to be considered sampled. We found that if only a small number (1-3) were sampled, those units were not often truly representative of others in that ancillary class, and the Intelligent Areal Weighting (IAW) method provided better results. Any class that is not preset or sufficiently sampled will be assigned a density using the IAW method. The default is 3.
param.pythonReference: This is the minimum threshold of representative source units required for an ancillary class to be considered sampled. We found that if only a small number (1-3) were sampled, those units were not often truly representative of others in that ancillary class, and the Intelligent Areal Weighting (IAW) method provided better results. Any class that is not preset or sufficiently sampled will be assigned a density using the IAW method. The default is 3.

param.name: Minimum_Sampling_Area
param.dialogReference: The minimum number of raster cells that may be considered "representative" of a source area. Increasing this number may eliminate some very small areas that might be considered anomalous outliers that could skew the class average. The default is 1.
param.pythonReference: The minimum number of raster cells that may be considered "representative" of a source area. Increasing this number may eliminate some very small areas that might be considered anomalous outliers that could skew the class average. The default is 1.

param.name: Percent
param.dialogReference: The script will calculate the percent area that each ancillary class covers in each source unit, and any source unit with an ancillary class above the percent area threshold will be considered representative of that class. Please specify the percent threshold value in decimal notation. The default is 0.95.
param.pythonReference: The script will calculate the percent area that each ancillary class covers in each source unit, and any source unit with an ancillary class above the percent area threshold will be considered representative of that class. Please specify the percent threshold value in decimal notation. The default is 0.95.

param.name: Output_Directory
param.dialogReference: The directory where all outputs from the tool will be saved.
param.pythonReference: The directory where all outputs from the tool will be saved.

tool.summary: The Intelligent Dasymetric Mapping (IDM) toolbox disaggregates population counts collected by vector source units (e.g., Census units) to the spatial resolution of a categorical ancillary raster containing classes that are indicative of the spatial distribution of population within the source units.
tool.usage:
Use of this tool may require increasing the maximum number of unique values the 'Combine Tool' can produce.

https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/tool-reference/spatial-analyst/combine.htm

The user can set a subjective representative population density for an ancillary class using their own domain knowledge by modifying the 'config.json' file in the toolbox's root directory.

The preset densities for the following land cover classes from the 2011 National Land Cover Database (NLCD) are set to 0 people per pixel:

  • 11, Open Water

  • 12, Perennial Ice/Snow

  • 95, Emergent Herbaceous Wetlands

The user can provide an optional uninhabited feature class. This feature class should contain polygons where no population are expected to reside. The polygons of the feature class are classified as an uninhabited ancillary class and the representative population density for this class is preset to 0 people per pixel.

dataIdInfo.idCredit: The Intelligent Dasymetric Toolbox for ArcGIS Pro was developed for EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas is a collaborative effort led by U.S. EPA that provides geospatial data, easy-to-use tools, and other resources related to ecosystem services, their stressors, and human health. The dasymetric toolbox was updated for ArcGIS Pro in January 2020 by Anam Khan1 and Jeremy Baynes2. This release also introduced optional functionality to mask known uninhabited areas. The toolbox was originally developed for ArcMap 10 by Torrin Hultgren3 The dasymetric toolbox follows the the methods by Mennis and Hultgren (2006)4. 1 Oak Ridge Associated Universities, National Student Services Contractor at the U.S. EPA 2 U.S. EPA 3 National Geospatial Support Team at U.S. EPA 4 Mennis, Jeremy & Hultgren, Torrin. (2006). Intelligent Dasymetric Mapping and Its Application to Areal Interpolation. Cartography and Geographic Information Science. 33. 179-194.

Consts.useLimit:
None. Acknowledgement of the EPA would be appreciated.
